displayed_text: Patient: You're right. Doctor: Okay, we have a medical student. I think they told you that he will be in. Did she tell you that? Patient: Yeah. That's right, yeah. That's right. Doctor: Um, okay, that um... Patient: That's fine. Patient: Good. The drops have been helping. Doctor: The redness is all gone. How about the tearing? Even that is better? Patient: Yeah, that's better. The pain-- Doctor: Okay. Patient: is, the drops help on that. There's no pain, the throb it’s not there. Doctor: Alright, then now let me see though (whispering) Patient: You were just covering it a little bit there. (pause) Doctor: This one is weeping?

Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff.

Healthcare Professional: …could you check and see if my insurance will cover it. Doctor: Yeah, no, no, absolutely. So sit tight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re gonna wait for S___. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The research nurse and then your appointment is as scheduled as per our normal follow-up. Okay? Patient: What is it six months,three months? Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months. Doctor: Three months with the blood test before. Patient: That’s right. Yeah, blood test before, two days before. Doctor: You got it. Patient: Boy was it was packed in here on Tuesday.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which actually will be sort of . So if you feel comfortable continuing with the next step, the next step will be for me to get a Patient: Okay. Yeah I’m interested uh huh so if the next step is I’ll read this and I’ll talk to my wife and my children and I’ve basically tell them this is the route that I wanted to go as far as radiation. I mean you’ve given me enough information with the random selection- Doctor: Correct. Patient: so I understand. My biggest concern is around the randmon selection is how long I’ll remain in that before actually having… Doctor: Right, now one thing to say about that and this is true of every clinical trial, you have the option to if you don’t want to. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But we, the is if you drop out Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but every once in a while we make an exception , but in general the cavet is dropping out early is you Patient: And this therapy is part of the trial, it’s not just something that’s being done, it’s associated with this trial. It’s not and say this is what I want to do at this time. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let us work on it. Patient: Okay. Alright. No problem. Doctor: Alright. Just, so you know. Because, this is a mighty expensive medication, and insurance does frequently give you and me the runaround Patient: Right. Doctor: Before they approve it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, we’re just used to it with everybody, and we Patient: Okay. Doctor: Expect questions. Patient: Okay. No prob. Doctor: Alright.

Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one? Patient: Yeah. Yeah, I guess. Doctor: So, I’ll print out the phase one and I’ll print out the immune therapy one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, those are two sort of, uh, things that you can be taking home and reading. Patient: Right. Doctor: I would stay with the current treatment for now.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: It’s just for a period of time. And then the last third, the cancer continued to grow at roughly the same pace that it was growing before. Patient: How so? Doctor: So the therapy did not appear to be effective. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what that looks like. Check it again for profiling, blueprinting of your genetics, I mean the whole nine yards. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We talked about that earlier. Patient: Right. Right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And if it’s time we do it. You know? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down. Family Member: Oh, okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. So, uh, if, so I guess the, the question is stay on this, this um, a clinic, stay in the clinical trial. Let’s see what happens the next, you know, three months from now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Is one option. And what other options are there? Doctor: Yeah. So, other options would be then we would stop this therapy and say that hey, you know, all the data says it’s gotten worse. Um, and, then we would look at other treatments. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: And the CAT scan. So that will be of your belly, your pelvis and your chest. Okay? Patient: Okay CAT scan is it’s not an MRI is it? Doctor: No. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Are you claustrophobic? Patient: Well no. (laughs) Doctor: And that was for your liver right? Patient: I guess so. Doctor: Yeah, So that’s different for your hepatitis. Patient: Now she says go down lower though. Doctor: Yes. So that side perfect. That will be helpful but not enough for us.

Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial? Doctor: Yeah, yeah that is part of it. Patient: So I’m in a new clinical trial basically. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And they’ll give me that as part of the clinical trial Doctor: Absolutely Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us? Doctor: Of gosh no that that you cannot get outside of the clinical trial. Patient: Really. Doctor: So you can’t get it if you tried. (Laughs) Patient: It’s so new. Uh and uh do you think within a month or two months we’ll know if it’s working? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah so I’m hoping to get you started within the next two or three weeks. Family Member: Oh yeah I mean we want to start right away.

Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh, they’re taping us now? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Oh, I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. We’re getting his whole lunch live right now in color Doctor: Well I’m glad you’re feeling a little better. Just you know take your time. We’re okay. We’ll see what that PSA shows. I’m glad we straightened out the whole pill action and everything else. Patient: Yeah. That’s all been handled.

Patient: Yes I am, yes I am. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yes I am. I wouldn’t take the new ones that you give me and the old ones too. No- Doctor: Alright. Patient: -because I know the old ones they they they hadn’t been any good for me but made me miserable. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here…

Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there. Doctor: Okay, that's fine. Let me print this out for you so that you can see what I'm talking about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll print both of them. Because the way that we, oh no there’s a lot of stuff coming out. So let me first sort of describe what we call like the stages of prostate cancer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: I’ll use the back of this. I think we talked about this last time, but I'll just, if I'm repeating myself and you get it, just say I remember all of this. So stages, so first you have what we call localized. Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian
